'''Joshua Barnes Howell''', known as '''Peg Leg Howell''' (March 5, 1888 - August 11, 1966),<ref>[http://users.efortress.com/doc-rock/1960.html Dead Rock Stars Club website data - accessed January 2008]</ref> was an [[African American]] [[blues]] [[singer]] and [[guitarist]], who connected early [[country blues]] and the later [[Twelve bar blues|12-bar]] style.<ref name="piedmont">[http://facstaff.unca.edu/sinclair/piedmontblues/howell.html East Coast Piedmont Blues website]</ref>

==Life and career==
He was born on a farm in [[Eatonton, Georgia|Eatonton]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States]], and taught himself [[guitar]] at the age of 21. Over time he became skilled in pre-Piedmont finger picking and [[slide guitar]] techniques. He continued working on the farm until he was shot in a fight, as a result of which he lost his right leg and began working full-time as a [[musician]].<ref name="piedmont"/> In 1923 he moved to [[Atlanta, Georgia]] and began playing on street corners, but also served a period in [[prison]] for [[rum-running|bootleg]]ging [[Distilled beverage|liquor]].  

In 1926, he was heard playing on the streets of Atlanta and was [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] for the first time by [[Columbia Records]].  They released "New Prison Blues", written while in prison and the first country blues to be issued on the label.<ref>[[Samuel Charters]]. ''[[The Country Blues (book)|The Country Blues]]''. New York: [[Da Capo Press]], 1975, p.148.</ref> Over the next three years Columbia recorded him on several occasions, often accompanied by a small group including Henry Williams on guitar and [[Eddie Anthony]] on [[fiddle]].  His recorded repertoire covered [[ballads]], [[ragtime]], and [[jazz]], as well as blues.

Howell continued to play around the Atlanta area for several years, but also began selling bootleg liquor again.  After the mid 1930s he only performed occasionally and, in 1952, his left leg was removed as a result of [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], confining him to a [[wheelchair]]. A single track by Howell was issued on ''[[The Country Blues]]'' in 1959, and in 1963 he was "rediscovered" in dire poverty in Atlanta by folklorist and field researcher [[George Mitchell (music historian)|George Mitchell]] and his high-school class-mate, Roger Brown. They recorded Howell at the age of 75 with the results issued on LP by [[Testament Records (USA)|Testament Records]] thirty-four years after his last recorded sessions, one of Mitchell's first field-recording sessions in his long career.<ref name="amg">[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p219143/biography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography]</ref>  Howell died in Atlanta in 1966.<ref name="amg"/>
